intro: Abutilon gaumeri, commonly known as the velvetleaf abutilon, is a shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its fuzzy, velvety leaves that give it a distinctive texture. The plant produces showy, spathate flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and requires well-drained soil. Abutilon gaumeri is often used in ornamental gardening for its attractive foliage and vibrant floral displays.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon gaumeri is primarily native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is found in regions such as Arizona, New Mexico, and parts of Sonora and Sinaloa. This plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, including rocky soils and dry slopes. It is commonly associated with desert scrub and chaparral habitats. Due to its limited range, it is considered a rare and endemic species in its native region.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon gaumeri was mainly introduced to the western United States, particularly in California and Oregon. It is commonly found in disturbed areas such as roadsides, fields, and along stream banks. This plant thrives in a variety of soil types but prefers well-drained conditions.
